body: @Kami   thanks for addressing the issues

I made a small change (5bbdc76244b29460e46c7bac4ff9ed4e64da02d6 - Argument only needs ``ex_`` prefix if it's an extension argument which is part of a standard API method. No need for the prefix if the method itself already contains ``ex_`` prefix.) and merged changes into trunk.

Thanks again for your contribution and sorry for the delay.
Thank you @Kami

Thanks for the contribution.

We have recently moved all the development away from JIRA to Github so the documentation is corrected - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1297.

All the references to JIRA were also removed from our website and replaced with Github. If you still find a reference to JIRA somewhere, let us know and we will fix it.

JIRA should also be read-only now so new issues can't be created anymore.

My bad, there are no issues in Github so thought the document was outdated.
Thanks for the clarification, will the issues be migrated over to Github issues now or only new issues are created in GitHub?

Old JIRA issues won't be migrated, but existing JIRA project will stay online in a read-only mode for the foreseeable future.

And as per ASF policy, all the existing JIRA issues (creation, updates, deletes, etc.) are also archived on the mailing list (so even if we delete the JIRA project or similar, all the old JIRA interactions are still archived).
see https://jira.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-961 and https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1143 for similar update in the past

Thanks for the contribution.

Change looks good to me :+1:

Merged, thanks.

@palashgandhi On a somewhat related note - how did you submit ICLA? We still haven't received it (it could just be that the person who's managing ICLAs at ASF is busy and hasn't had the time to process it yet).
Yes, it should be safe since it's just a public key.
Yeah that's what I thought, I have uploaded it. Lmk if you need anything else from me.
Please just let the ASF secretary know that you have uploaded your public key since this may speed up the processing.
@Kami I had emailed him already. Can you please let me know when you receive it? I just want to make sure this goes through.

@palashgandhi You should receive an email when your ICLA is processed and we should be CCed on it. 

I've seen some ICLAs were processed today, but I haven't seen yours yet.

Thank you for your contribution.

We will review it when we get a chance.

I've merged changes into trunk. Thanks for a great contribution!

When you get a chance, it would great if you can test the change I made in 8e2e9b18d0db61cb16947ce00f227c76e944f13c against the real provider API. All the tests do pass, bit that's not a guarantee it works end to end :)
Merged, thanks.
I can confirm your change works as expected against the real API. Thanks for your help @Kami!

It turns out this will be quite a challenging and painful task.

Existing type annotations I added already uncovered some issues with sub-classes not handling parent types correctly, etc.

We don't have much choice here, but to use a type annotation work around in such scenarios (supporting multiple types aka Union), because we can't break the API.

In addition to that, it will also be hard to come up with good type annotations for our dynamic ``get_driver`` and other factory methods.

In addition to my comment above - I also decided I will start with an API per pull request to make sure the PRs don't grow too large.

In this PR I will work on the compute API and other common code which is needed to get that to work.

As far as type annotations for our dynamically returned provider drivers go - I still haven't been able to figure this out.

We may just need to go with returning a reference to the base NodeDriver. It's not ideal since it won't know about any provider class specific methods and arguments, but I'm not even sure yet if we can correctly annotate our code which does our dynamic driver class loading (we may need a MyPy plugin or it may even not be possible).

@tonybaloney ^ maybe you have an idea if we can get type annotations to work for our dynamically loaded and returned driver classes.

For now, I have this - f5a201637f517c86128ef049314996e3bc97e195. As mentioned above, it's not ideal since it won't be aware of any provider driver class specific methods and arguments.

I did quite a lot of research and experimentation and I couldn't get it to work (aka annotate ``get_driver`` method that it returns a reference to provider driver class which is dependent on the value of provided ``provider`` argument constant).

I believe we may only be able to achieve that using a custom MyPy plugin (but I could be wrong).

Thanks for the patience @Kami. The ICLA is now signed.

I've made some fixes and changes and merged PR into master (please see a list of changes I made here - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/commits/trunk).

In theory ``deploy_node`` should also work now, but I didn't test it. Something along those lines:

```python
ssh_key = driver.list_key_pairs()[0]
ssh_key_uuid = ssh_key.fingerprint

auth = NodeAuthSSHKey(ssh_key.pubkey)

node = conn.deploy_node(name='test', image=image], size=size, auth=auth,
                        deploy=..., ex_ssh_key_ids=[ssh_key_uuid])
```

Thanks again for the contribution.
[All integration tests pass](https://clewolff.visualstudio.com/libcloud-tests/_build/results?buildId=271) with this branch.

Superseded by #1282 so I'm closing this PR.

I started to look into this today. Sadly the change will be much more involved than I was hoping for.

Part of the issue is related to "set_http_proxy" driver method which doesn't work correctly because of the way how connection class is instantiated. This was either broken when moving to the requests library or it never worked correctly.

Superseded by #1314.

Thanks again for your contribution. I will get it finished inside #1314.

I tried to test and get deployment to work, but it turned out it a huge time sink.

Main problem is that paramiko only supports key files in old PKCS#1 PEM format. New style OpenSSH keys or key files in PEM format without `---BEGIN <type> PRIVATE KEY` header are not supported.

I updated the code to handle such scenario better:

1. Propagate "invalid key file" exception to the user instead of re-trying the deployment.
2. If user passes in a key file which contains private key in a PEM format, but without a valid header we try to manually convert into into a format which paramiko accepts.

We also need to add a note to our deployment documentation which clearly says what kind of keys paramiko supports so users won't waste as much time as I did on this.
